predictions.reasoning: Author vishaltandale00 has 0% merge rate across 11 prior PRs. PR #9093 is a superseding fix by a different author (divol89) that addresses the same Discord mention detection issue with a more focused scope. Member comment from thewilloftheshadow on #9093 explicitly states it 'already fixes limited-intent mention detection' making #9086 redundant. Additionally, #9086 has failing CI (formatting check failure noted in review) and author self-review comments indicating incomplete fixes. This is a classic supersession pattern (P-2-1, P-3-1, P-4-2).

Member thewilloftheshadow explicitly closes this PR as a duplicate/supersession: 'Closing as a [duplicate], which already fixes limited-intent mention detection with a minimal text fallback and focused tests.' The closure comment explicitly references that another PR (implied to be #9086) already provides the fix with a more focused scope. This is a terminal non-merge signal per P-2-1 and P-3-1. Author divol89 is a first-time contributor (0 prior PRs) without maintainer label or approval.

Author 1kuna explicitly closes the PR in favor of #10585: 'Closing in favor of #10585, which consolidates this lane task timeout safety net with the compaction lane-lock fix.' This is a direct author supersession statement (P-1-2). The author reinforces this with a second comment: 'This fix has been consolidated into #10585'. Terminal non-merge signal. Additionally, author has 0% merge rate across 4 prior PRs, and the PR has only automated reviews with AI Council concerns noted, no human approval.

Author mudrii explicitly closes the PR: 'Closing this PR as the TUI accessibility feature has been deprioritized. The per-channel responsePrefix functionality is already...' (text cut off, but intent is clear). This is a terminal author-initiated closure indicating the work is no longer wanted, regardless of the 100% prior merge rate (1/1) and positive greptile review. The closure signals deprioritization, not technical rejection, but the PR is still closed and will not merge. Author is a CONTRIBUTOR with prior merge success, but the explicit closure statement overrides positive signals.

Author akoscz has 0% merge rate across 2 prior PRs and exhibits persistent self-advocacy pattern without human reviewer engagement or approval. Despite 18 reviews (all from greptile-apps automated reviewer and self), there is no human approval or maintainer comment/label. Author repeatedly pings greptile-apps for re-reviews ('review the PR again', 'ok dude, review the PR once more', 'please review this PR') which signals frustration with engagement rather than progress. Size L (7 files) combined with 0% author history, no human reviews, and no maintainer signal triggers P-4-2 (XL-sized from 0% merge author with no human engagement). PR is functionally mature but lacks the gatekeeping signal needed for merge.

XL-sized PR (38 files) from first-time contributor smartprogrammer93 (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with no maintainer label, no human reviewer approval, and only automated greptile review. Triggers P-4-1: 'Large feature PRs (XL size, 20+ files) from first-time contributors without maintainer labels are unlikely to merge regardless of author engagement or review cycles.' The Android companion app feature with gateway URL camera payloads is substantial scope change. No human engagement, no maintainer signals, and XL size combined with 0% author history creates compounded non-merge signal per P-4-2.

Author tangcruz has 0% merge rate across 6 prior PRs. PR is L-sized (8 files) with cross-channel awareness scope. Author comment states: 'Consolidating into fewer self-contained PRs to resolve cross-PR type dependencies.' This signals the PR is being abandoned in favor of a refactored approach, not merged. No human approval, no maintainer label or comment. First-time context for this specific feature (cross-channel awareness) combined with 0% author history and medium-large scope (8 files, L-sized) with stated consolidation/refactoring intent triggers non-merge. The comment suggests work is being split across multiple PRs rather than merged as-is.

Author Limitless2023 explicitly closes the PR: 'Closing — variable shadowing bug makes the transcription result unused. Will resubmit a corrected fix.' Greptile identified duplicate `wasMentioned` declaration causing compile error and variable shadowing bug (line 137 vs line 163). Author acknowledges the bug and states intent to resubmit separately, making this PR terminal closure. Despite author having 12.5% merge rate (1/8 prior PRs) and focused S-sized scope, the explicit author closure statement with technical acknowledgment of a blocking bug is a terminal non-merge signal. Author will submit a corrected version separately.

Author BinHPdev closes the PR: 'Closing: CI infrastructure changes carry higher risk; consolidating open PRs.' Author explicitly states the closure rationale is risk avoidance and PR consolidation strategy. Despite XS size (2 files), focused scope (CI + test fix), and author history of 55 prior PRs with 5.5% merge rate (3 merged), the explicit author closure overrides technical merit. The 'consolidating open PRs' language mirrors #15555/#9288 pattern: work is being reorganized across multiple PRs rather than merged as-is. Terminal author-initiated closure with stated strategic rationale.

First-time contributor Threadm-ind (0 prior PRs) with S-sized PR (8 files) covering security documentation and dependency exception guard infrastructure (scripts, CI workflows, docs). No explicit closure comment, no maintainer label, no human reviewer comments or approvals. However, the PR addresses a clear documentation/infrastructure gap (SECURITY.md, dependency-exceptions.md, check-dependency-exceptions script). CI status unknown. Size S and focused scope (documentation + scripts) are moderate signals. Greptile review not visible in the PR data. Without maintainer label (P-5-6 pattern warning), first-time contributor PRs with zero human reviewer engagement rarely merge. However, docs-focused PRs have slightly higher baseline merge rates, and the infrastructure work is defensible. Confidence is moderate-low due to lack of human engagement and maintainer signals, but above 0.5 due to focused, valuable scope and docs-category baseline strength.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with docs-only XS PR. Only automated review from greptile-apps; zero human reviewer engagement, zero approvals, zero maintainer label. Pattern P-5-6 applies: docs-only PRs from first-time contributors without human reviewer comments or approvals do not reliably merge. Narrow scope insufficient to overcome engagement absence.

Author mcaxtr has 7 prior PRs with 0% merge rate. PR is XL-sized (103 files) with only automated review from greptile-apps. No human reviewer engagement, no approvals, no maintainer label. Only a self-comment from author clarifying the scope. Patterns P-2-5 and P-4-4 apply: XL-sized PRs from authors with 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs and zero human reviewer engagement are very unlikely to merge. No commit-hash-backed merge receipt present to override.

Author explicitly closed PR with statement: 'Closing: post message type support is already in upstream main (commit 5f6e1c19b).' This is a supersession signal (pattern P-5-1 / P-5-4 adjacent). Author comment stating the work is already in main is a terminal non-merge signal. Additionally, author cszhouwei has 2 prior PRs with 0% merge rate, only automated review, and no human engagement.

Author joeykrug has 2 prior PRs with 0% merge rate. S-sized PR (2 files) with only automated review from greptile-apps. Zero human reviewer comments, zero approvals, no maintainer label. Pattern P-4-4 applies: XS-XL-sized PRs from authors with 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs and no human reviewer engagement are very unlikely to merge. No commit-hash-backed merge receipt to override.

Author maxesisnclaw explicitly closed PR with: 'Closing — this fix has been [merged elsewhere], which introduced a centralized extractDeliveryInfo()'. This is a supersession/duplicate-fix signal (pattern P-5-1, P-5-4). Author states the work landed in another PR with broader scope. Additionally, author has 1 prior PR with 0% merge rate, confirming low merge likelihood even absent the explicit closure statement.

Author quotentiroler has strong history: 11 prior PRs with 9 merged (81.8% merge rate). M-sized refactor PR (6 files) with labels indicating scope (scripts, agents). Only automated review from greptile-apps, flagging an abort error shape change concern. No human reviewer approval yet, but high author merge rate and focused scope support merge prediction. Refactor + bug fix combo typical of project. No negative terminal signals (no supersession, no revert, no duplicate closure). Author's track record overrides absence of human review for this medium-complexity refactor.

Author aisling404 explicitly closed PR with: 'Closing — the changelog has moved on enough that this entry would be out of place now.' This is an author self-closure statement indicating the PR is not mergeable (outdated, out of scope). First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with docs-only XS change. Zero human engagement, zero maintainer label. Pattern P-3-2 and general author closure signal indicate non-merge.

Member thewilloftheshadow explicitly stated intent to close PR: 'I will be closing this PR and implementing it myself.' This is a terminal non-merge signal despite the PR receiving a non-maintainer approval from HenryLoenwind. Member rejection overrides community approval. Additionally, author robbyczgw-cla has 6 prior PRs with only 1 merged (16.7% merge rate), and has experienced-contributor label but no maintainer label. Member's stated intent to reimplement rather than merge this PR is definitive.

Author jasonftl has strong history: 1 prior PR with 1 merged (100% merge rate). XS-sized PR (2 files) with clear scope. Author explicitly stated closure comment: 'same fix, submitted a few minutes earlier. Closing in favour of that PR' (referencing #16231). However, author's later comment confirms: 'Looks like this fix landed on main - the log line now uses params.data.guild_id. Thanks @thewilloftheshadow for getting it in!' This indicates the fix DID land on main, suggesting this PR was merged or its code was absorbed. Author's 100% merge rate + confirmation that code landed on main indicates merge occurred (likely via rebase/manual cherry-pick or direct acceptance of equivalent fix by maintainer). Treat author's final comment as implicit merge receipt.

Author obviyus has strong history: 11 prior PRs with 9 merged (81.8% merge rate). S-sized feature PR (13 files) with maintainer label and agents category. Formal models conformance drift flagged by github-actions (informational, non-blocking). Author provided visual demo (playful 🦞 emoji + GIF demonstrating feature). Has automated review from greptile-apps. Maintainer label is strong positive signal (90.7% merge rate per guidelines). Author's high merge rate (81.8%) + maintainer label + S-sized scope + animated demo indicating feature completeness support merge prediction. Formal models drift is non-blocking per comment. No terminal negative signals (no supersession, no revert, no duplicate closure).

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with XS scope (2 files), but zero human reviewer engagement beyond automated greptile comments. No approval, no maintainer label, and Takhoffman's comment suggests overlapping intent with another fix (duplicate pattern). No explicit merge signal or maintainer approval to override low merge baseline for first-time contributors.

Author's own comment explicitly acknowledges PR #4844 as the superseding PR and states efforts to align with it. Glucksberg (CONTRIBUTOR) flagged as duplicate. sebslight (MEMBER) comment states 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen' — strong closure signal. Terminal non-merge per P-1-2 (supersession) and P-3-1 (explicit duplicate notice). Author with 0% merge rate (0/1) does not override explicit supersession statement.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate). Glucksberg (CONTRIBUTOR) explicitly flags as duplicate of PR #4997. Author's comment acknowledges the duplicate and states the fix is implemented in #4997 with tests included. Terminal non-merge per P-1-2 (supersession) and P-3-1. Medium-large scope (11 files) with no maintainer label or approval. Greptile comments do not constitute human reviewer engagement/approval.

CRITICAL: PR has 0 files changed (no diff). Per P-4-3, zero-file PRs cannot be merged regardless of any other signals. Author safaiyeh's comment 'Closing - this fix was already' (incomplete but clear closure intent) confirms terminal non-merge. mverrilli's positive engagement comments are overridden by the zero-file constraint and author closure statement.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) with large scope (19 files, touches extensions + docs). sebslight (MEMBER) comment explicitly directs to issue #5799 and contributing guidelines, signaling scope misalignment and process violation. New feature proposal (not a fix) from first-time contributor without maintainer label or approval. Multiple greptile review cycles without resolution suggest unresolved concerns. Terminal non-merge per P-3-3 (no maintainer approval) combined with process/scope concerns.

Author revenuestack has 0% merge rate across 3 prior PRs (is_low_merge_author=true). Per P-4-1, authors with 0% merge rate across 2+ prior PRs without maintainer engagement are unlikely to merge. sebslight's (MEMBER) comment 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen' is a strong closure signal. Only greptile automated review, no human reviewer approval. Medium scope (5 files, multi-area). No maintainer label.

TERMINAL POSITIVE MERGE SIGNAL: mbelinky (CONTRIBUTOR) comment contains explicit merge receipt language: 'Landed on `main` via squash commits: - 730f86dd5...' with commit hash 730f86dd5. Per P-2-2, commit-hash-backed merge statements constitute terminal positive signals overriding all negative indicators (author 0% merge rate on 4 prior PRs, no maintainer label, large scope 24 files). Follow-up closure comment 'Closed: already landed on main via 730f86dd5' confirms merge completion. Ground truth: MERGED.

TERMINAL POSITIVE MERGE SIGNAL: mbelinky (CONTRIBUTOR) comment contains explicit merge receipt language: 'Landed on `main` via squash commits: - 6aedc54bd iOS: alpha node app + setup-code onboarding (#11756)' with commit hash 6aedc54bd. Per P-2-2, commit-hash-backed merge statements override all negative signals. Author has 0% merge rate (0/5 prior PRs), extremely large scope (49 files), no maintainer label — all overridden by explicit merge commit hash. Follow-up closure comment confirms merge completion. Ground truth: MERGED.

Author 0xRaini's own comment explicitly states: 'Closing — these tests assume the old broad billing-error regex. PR #13827 narrows the regex and includes its own comprehensive false-positive tests in `isBillingErrorMessage.test.ts`, which supersedes these.' Terminal non-merge per P-1-2 (author explicitly declares supersession by another PR). Author's strong prior history (5.7% merge rate on 35 PRs) does not override the author's own explicit supersession statement per P-3-2.

Author dakshaymehta has 100% merge rate (1/1 prior PR merged). XS-sized focused fix (2 files, commands category). Has maintainer label 'size: XS'. No draft status. Green CI inferred from lack of CI failure signals. However, no human reviewer comments or approvals present, and 100% rate is derived from single prior PR. Per P-5-6, require either human reviewer engagement OR maintainer label for authors with 100% rate from <3 prior PRs. The size: XS label provides weak maintainer signal. Baseline merge rate for XS with 1 prior merge is moderate-to-good (~40-50% empirically). Conservative positive prediction.

Terminal positive signal: MEMBER comment (sebslight) includes explicit merge language ('Landed on main with:') accompanied by two commit hashes (63c9fac9f, 0fa55ed2b). Per P-2-2, commit-hash-backed merge receipts are terminal positive signals overriding all other factors, including first-time contributor status and zero prior merge rate. The comment also references contributor credit addition, confirming the merge.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with no title/description context provided, single file change to README.md, no human reviewer comments or approvals (only automated Greptile review), no maintainer label, no engagement signals. Per P-5-5, PRs with vague/missing descriptions and zero review activity from human reviewers are unreliable merge candidates. Minimal scope and single file suggest incomplete or placeholder work.

Author (Zazarothh) has 0% merge rate across 9 prior PRs. Per P-4-1, authors with 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs (4+) are very unlikely to merge new PRs. Additionally, Greptile review identifies a critical code defect: 'Undefined variable used' — `uniqueSkillCommands` is referenced but never defined in the function. The PR has failing code quality despite being a bug fix attempt. No human reviewer engagement, no approval, no maintainer comment. This is a non-merge candidate.

Author (Zazarothh) now has 0% merge rate across 10 prior PRs (incremental attempt). Greptile review again identifies same critical defect: 'Undefined variable used' — `uniqueSkillCommands` still not defined. This is v4, following v3 (#10914), suggesting iterative attempts to fix the same issue but failing to resolve the core problem. No human reviewer engagement. Per P-4-1, 0% merge rate authors without maintainer approval or label are unlikely to merge even with multiple attempts.

Author (Zazarothh) now has 0% merge rate across 14 prior PRs (v6 attempt, third iteration on same fix). Despite adding test file, Greptile identifies the core defect persists: 'Reserved commands still duplicated' — the logic still populates from the pre-deduplicated list, defeating the purpose. Per P-4-1, authors with persistent 0% merge rate across 14+ prior PRs are very unlikely to merge, especially when iterations fail to resolve identified issues. No human reviewer approval or maintainer engagement.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with M-sized feature PR (6 files) adding Discord exec approval cleanup option. Has maintainer label (90.7% merge rate per historical data) and human reviewer approval from Ari4ka. However, per P-5-7, maintainer label alone without human reviewer comment/approval on first-time contributor PRs is weak. The approval from Ari4ka provides the missing human engagement signal. The combination of maintainer label + human approval + focused feature scope supports merge prediction, though the absence of prior merge history and detailed context introduces moderate uncertainty.

Terminal non-merge signal: MEMBER comment from thewilloftheshadow explicitly states 'Auto-closing PR, shtse8 has been blocked due to spamming PRs and letting AI agents send slop and clogging our review queue'. This is an explicit closure announcement from a maintainer. The author (shtse8) has been flagged for problematic behavior and blocked. Even though the author has 88 prior PRs with 5 merged, the explicit blocking and closure statement from a member override all other signals.

Multiple terminal non-merge signals: (1) XL-sized PR with 18 files, high complexity. (2) First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate). (3) CONTRIBUTOR comment from HenryLoenwind explicitly states 'This PR is malicious.' (4) MEMBER comment from thewilloftheshadow responds 'Are you stupid?' indicating dismissal/hostility. (5) PR touches multiple workflow files and extensions with modifications to CI/CD pipelines (.github/workflows), which is a high-risk pattern. The malicious characterization and dismissive member response are explicit rejection signals. Per patterns around XL PRs from first-time contributors without maintainer engagement, combined with explicit malicious flagging, this is a certain non-merge.

XL-sized PR (5285 files changed, 100+ shown) with massive scope touching 38 labels including security, all channels, extensions, docker, agents. Despite author (arosstale) having 85 prior PRs with 7.1% merge rate (relatively low), this PR violates the fundamental principle in P-3-4: 'XL-sized PRs (15+ files) from authors with 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs and no human reviewer engagement are very unlikely to merge.' While arosstale is not 0%, the PR has failed Greptile review (mock leak identified) and the scope is enormous. Additionally, the PR has 38 labels which suggests automated triage pressure. Although arosstale responded to fix the mock leak (89caa3c), the sheer scope and the fact that it triggered critical review issues make this a non-merge candidate. The fix attempt does not override the massive scope and complexity concerns. This is a typical 'too large to merge' signal pattern.

Author (BinHPdev) has 0% merge rate across 4 prior PRs (exactly at threshold). Per P-4-1, authors with 0% merge rate across 4+ prior PRs are unlikely to merge new PRs. XS-sized PR (2 files) with focused commands category scope. Greptile review present (automated only). No human reviewer comments or approvals. No maintainer engagement or label. The combination of 0% prior merge rate + no human reviewer engagement + no maintainer signals creates a low-probability merge scenario. The technical scope (type safety for models status command) is narrow, but the author's persistent rejection history is a strong negative signal.

Member comment indicates closure: 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' This is a terminal closure signal. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with only automated review engagement and a member closure statement. Pattern P-5-1 equivalent: member explicit closure is a non-merge signal.

Medium-sized feature PR (1 file, M-scope inferred) from contributor with 0% prior merge rate (0/2). However, member engagement from gumadeiras who stated 'I'll take a look at it today or tomorrow' signals active maintainer consideration. Author engagement is responsive. No explicit non-merge signal. Pattern P-7 warns against relying on community discussion alone without maintainer approval, but the gumadeiras MEMBER comment indicates actual engagement rather than passive discussion. Active maintainer engagement + focused fix + author responsiveness moderates low merge-rate signal.

Author explicitly closed the PR: 'Closing in favor of #10612' and '#10612 (targeted first-chunk-only fix)'. This is an author supersession statement. Pattern P-1-2 and P-2-1: explicit supersession by the author is a terminal non-merge signal, even though the fix is technically focused. The work was absorbed by PR #10612.

Author comment states: 'which covers the announce bypass fix along with the followup drain on error paths.' This references another PR (implicit supersession). Combined with author's 0% merge rate (0/2 prior PRs) and no human reviewer approval, this is a non-merge signal. Author is implicitly indicating work was consolidated elsewhere. Pattern P-1-2 (author supersession statement).

Contributor Glucksberg states: 'This appears to duplicate PR #3392, which implements the same fix.' Contributor clawdinator responds: 'closing in favor of that PR.' This is an explicit duplicate closure with reference to superseding PR #3392. Pattern P-5-1 and P-1-2: duplicate closure with another PR reference is a terminal non-merge signal. Additionally, author has 0% merge rate (0/23 prior PRs), which is a severe negative signal even without the duplicate indicator.

MEMBER steipete provides explicit merge receipt: 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' with prepared head SHA and merge commit SHA (both present). This is a terminal positive merge signal per Pattern P-2-2 (commit-hash-backed merge confirmation). The merge receipt overrides all other signals including author's 0% prior merge rate (0/1). Author is CONTRIBUTOR status, PR is M-sized (3 files), focused slack feature. Merge metadata includes both commit hashes and explicit merge language, which is conclusive.

MEMBER thewilloftheshadow explicitly closes PR: 'Auto-closing PR, shtse8 has been blocked due to spamming PRs and letting AI agents send slop and clogging our review queue'. This is an explicit closure with author-level blocking action. Terminal non-merge signal regardless of PR technical quality or prior merge rate. Author is blocked from contributions.

Author 0xRaini has strong prior merge rate (20/113 = 17.7%), which is above baseline. PR is XS-sized (3 files), focused fix replacing hardcoded /tmp path with os.tmpdir(). CI status unknown but greptile provided code review. No explicit non-merge signal. However, no human reviewer approval and no maintainer comment or label present. Pattern P-5-6 suggests caution: even with prior merge rate above baseline, absence of human reviewer engagement is concerning. Greptile comment is informational (outdated help string note), not an approval. Moderate confidence due to author track record but tempered by lack of human validation.

Author steipete is MEMBER with 100% merge rate (14/14 prior PRs). PR has maintainer label and S-sized scope (5 files, agents/sandbox refactor). Multiple automated reviews present (greptile, codex, cursor). No explicit non-merge signals. No human reviewer concerns or blocking comments. Maintainer label combined with author's perfect merge history strongly indicates merge. Automated reviews provide technical validation even without human approval. Terminal positive indicators: maintainer label + maintainer status author + 100% prior merge rate.

MEMBER/CONTRIBUTOR mbelinky provides explicit merge receipt: 'Merged into `main` via deterministic squash flow' with 'Prep head SHA' and 'Merge commit SHA' explicitly present (hashes redacted but structure confirms). This is a terminal positive merge signal per Pattern P-2-2 (commit-hash-backed merge confirmation). Merge language is explicit and references both prepared head and merge commit SHAs. Author has strong prior merge rate (7/15 = 46.7%). PR is L-sized (8 files) with maintainer label and cli/gateway category. Formal models drift is informational only (not blocking). Merge receipt overrides all other signals.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs) with docs-only PR (6 files). Only automated review from greptile-apps; zero human reviewer comments or approvals. Per P-5-6, docs-only PRs from first-time contributors require either human reviewer engagement or maintainer label to merge. No maintainer label present. The automated review alone is insufficient without human validation.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with focused fix (5 files, app:macos). Author explicitly closes the PR stating intent to 'recreate it as an independent branch from main' — this is a self-supersession signal. The PR will not be merged in its current form; the author plans to reopen it separately. Per P-3-1, author statements of supersession/rework are terminal non-merge signals.

Contributor with established merge history (22 prior PRs, 7 merged, 31.8% merge rate) and trusted-contributor label. M-sized PR (9 files, cli category) with greptile review. Critical signal: steipete (CONTRIBUTOR, likely high-trust participant) posts merge receipt comment: 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' with merge commit hash. Per P-2-2, commit-hash-backed merge statements are terminal positive signals overriding all other factors. This is a confirmed merge.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with agents category PR (5 files). Community discussion shows HenryLoenwind (CONTRIBUTOR) explicitly rejects the approach twice, stating 'That is the wrong way to do this' and recommending separate agents/sandboxing instead. Author acknowledges the feedback and agrees the approach is flawed. This represents a rejection of the PR's core approach by a knowledgeable contributor. No maintainer label, no approval, and fundamental design objection. Per pattern consensus, PRs with design-intent rejection comments from established contributors are not merged.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with small, focused fix (S-sized, 4 files, docker category). Critical engagement signal: asklee-klawd (CONTRIBUTOR) provides two positive review comments praising the fix ('Nice fix!', 'Great fix!', 'clean and well-tested'). This constitutes human reviewer engagement and tacit approval. Per P-1-1 and engagement patterns, small scope + positive human review + no maintainer objections = likely merge despite first-time status. CI passing (implied by successful test references). Greptile review also present. The positive reviewer endorsement and narrow scope overcome first-time contributor barrier.

Author 0xRaini (124 prior PRs, 20 merged, 16.1% merge rate) explicitly closes this PR with comment 'Closing — created from wrong branch, will redo if needed.' This is a self-closure and supersession signal. The PR will not be merged; the author plans to recreate it from the correct branch. Per P-3-1, author statements of supersession or rework are terminal non-merge signals. Additionally, greptile review is the only feedback (no human reviewer engagement).

Author 0xRaini (131 prior PRs, 21 merged, 16.0% merge rate) opens a duplicate PR (#14923) after closing #14886 for branch issues. However, thewilloftheshadow (MEMBER) posts a critical comment: 'Banning user due to spam/slop + copying other users PRs and pinging users'. This is a member-initiated user ban and moderation action. A member ban comment indicating spam/slop and PR copying is a terminal non-merge signal that overrides all technical signals. The user will not merge this PR; the account is being moderated for problematic behavior.

Author robbyczgw-cla (15 prior PRs, 7 merged, 46.7% merge rate, experienced-contributor label) posts closure comment: 'Closing — and #16536 which were submitted earlier. Same fix approach.' This is an author-initiated supersession statement. The author is closing this PR in favor of earlier PRs (#16536, implied others) that share the same fix approach. Per P-3-1, author supersession statements are terminal non-merge signals. The PR will not be merged; the fix is being handled by a preceding/parallel PR.

Author joshp123 (13 prior PRs, 9 merged, 69.2% merge rate) with maintainer label and S-sized PR (10 files, agents category). Critical merge signal: joshp123 (CONTRIBUTOR) posts merge receipt comment: 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' with merge commit hash and explicit gate information. Per P-2-2 and P-2-3, commit-hash-backed merge statements are terminal positive signals overriding all other factors. This is a confirmed merge. The maintainer label, high prior merge rate, and focused scope all reinforce the signal.

First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0.0% merge rate) with XS-sized README doc change (1 file). Two community concerns: (1) mrmcsmartypants1 reports authentication/permission errors (403); (2) HenryLoenwind (CONTRIBUTOR) flags the link as 'Looks suspicious. Possibly link to malicious software.' Author responds defensively rather than addressing security concern substantively. Per P-1-1, when a contributor raises a security/trust concern about external links in documentation, and the author's response is defensive without maintainer backing, the PR is unlikely to merge. No maintainer label, no maintainer engagement, and unresolved security concern from an established contributor.

Contributor comment from vignesh07 (CONTRIBUTOR role) explicitly states 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' with merge commit reference. This is a terminal positive merge signal per P-2-2 (commit-hash-backed merge receipt overrides all signals). Author is first-time contributor (0 prior PRs), but merge receipt is authoritative. Size S, 6 files changed, CI green (implied by test gate mention). Category: channel:signal.

Member sebslight comment states 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen' — implies PR has been closed. The truncated nature of the comment suggests closure has already occurred. First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate), no merge receipt, no human reviewer approval beyond automated greptile. Agents category, 6 files, size M (implied). Member comment closure is terminal non-merge signal.

Author's final comment '@sebslight why did you close this?' indicates PR was already closed by a member (sebslight). First-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate), XS docs PR with 3 files. Author self-advocacy without human reviewer approval per P-5-7. No merge receipt. The fact that author questions closure indicates it was closed by member action, terminal non-merge signal.

Author odrobnik (CONTRIBUTOR, 2 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) explicitly states 'Merged into #9553 instead' — this is a terminal non-merge signal per P-3-1 (author supersession comment). Work was absorbed by another PR #9553. Regardless of PR size (9 files, M), scope, or automated reviews, the author's own declaration of supersession is authoritative and overrides all other signals.

Author arosstale (CONTRIBUTOR, 60 prior PRs, 0% merge rate) explicitly states 'Closing — PR #11731 already covers these languages (and 14 more) with full 313-page translations. This was a duplicate.' duplicates.evidence: Both PRs address Discord mention detection with limited message content intent. PR #9093 (divol89) is explicitly marked as the canonical fix by member thewilloftheshadow who states #9093 'already fixes limited-intent mention detection with a minimal text fallback and focused tests' and closes it as a duplicate, implying #9086 is the superseded PR. Both touch src/discord/monitor/message-handler.preflight.ts and fix the same underlying issue (mentionedUsers incomplete array handling). #9093 adds broader behavior changes (role-mention detection + cron tweaks) that were explicitly rejected in favor of #9086's more focused approach, but the member closure comment indicates #9086 is the chosen fix. Reverse supersession: #9086 is the target, #9093 is superseded.

Both PRs from 0% merge-rate authors (1kuna: 0/4, tangcruz: 0/6) who explicitly state their work is being consolidated into other PRs. Both authors close their PRs citing consolidation strategy rather than technical rejection. #9288 author states 'Closing in favor of #10585, which consolidates this lane task timeout safety net with the compaction lane-lock fix.' #15555 author states 'Consolidating into fewer self-contained PRs to resolve cross-PR type dependencies.' While these are different features (lane task timeout vs. cross-channel awareness), the pattern is identical: work is being refactored and merged into alternative PR(s) rather than merged independently. Not direct duplicates but part of same consolidation/refactoring strategy.

Both PRs fix the same Discord guild_id logging issue (#16207). Author jasonftl of #16283 explicitly states: 'same fix, submitted a few minutes earlier. Closing in favour of that PR' (referencing #16231). Both PRs modify src/discord/monitor/message-handler.preflight.ts and both address the raw event guild_id in inbound message logging. #16231 from robbyczgw-cla is the earlier submitted PR; #16283 from jasonftl is the later PR that was superseded. jasonftl's closure comment + maintainer thewilloftheshadow's intention to reimplement confirms #16231 was prioritized.

Glucksberg (CONTRIBUTOR) flags PR #4476 as duplicate of PR #4844 ('PR #4844 appears to implement the same fix'). Author kira-ariaki acknowledges and states: 'I've updated this PR to match the scope of #4844'. Clear supersession: PR #4844 is the canonical fix with tests included.

Author 0xRaini explicitly closes PR #13725, stating: 'Closing — these tests assume the old broad billing-error regex. PR #13827 narrows the regex and includes its own comprehensive false-positive tests in `isBillingErrorMessage.test.ts`, which supersedes these.' Clear supersession by PR #13827.

Both PRs from same author (mbelinky), created within 19 seconds of each other (11755 at 08:12:11Z, 11756 at 08:12:28Z). Commit SHAs in both merge receipts reference a stack: 11755 lands 730f86dd5 (base), 11756 lands 6aedc54bd with 730f86dd5 as base. mbelinky's comments reference stack continuation. These are stacked PRs (common pattern), not true duplicates, but semantically related as a coordinated feature bundle. Confidence reduced due to stack-pattern clarity.

Three sequential attempts (v3, v4, v6) by same author (Zazarothh) on identical fix topic: 'deduplicate skill commands in bot native commands menu (#10875)'. All three PRs reference issue #10875, target same file (src/telegram/bot-native-commands.ts), and attempt to resolve the same deduplication logic. PR #9285 author explicitly states 'Closing in favor of #10612 (targeted first-chunk-only fix)'. Supersession relationship with explicit PR reference. Work consolidated into #10612.

PR #9286 author comment references another PR covering 'the announce bypass fix along with the followup drain on error paths'. Similar announce/queue logic scope. Likely consolidated with #10612 or related fix PR.

PR #9840: Contributor Glucksberg identifies: 'This appears to duplicate PR #3392, which implements the same fix.' Explicit duplicate detection by contributor. Contributor clawdinator confirms 'closing in favor of that PR'.

PR #14625 author states: 'This is a clean resubmission of #6534 — rebased fresh on main'. Explicit resubmission relationship. Original PR #6534 presumably closed, new version submitted as #14625 with merge confirmation.

Both PRs from author 0xRaini, same title 'fix(feishu): compute CommandAuthorized dynamically instead of hardcoding true', same 1 file changed (extensions/feishu/src/bot.ts), same XS size, same channel:feishu label. PR #16564 author-closure comment states 'Same fix approach' as #16536 (and others submitted earlier). Both address media/binary MIME type handling per the PR titles. PR #12171 adds Italian, German, Dutch, Spanish, Arabic, Portuguese translations (6 languages, 31 files). PR #18070 (47 files, XL, stale ancestry) is superseded by PR #18091 (narrow 6-file diff, clean branch from main). Author ciberponk explicitly states in PR #16404 comment: 'Superseded by English re-submission: https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw/pull/16417'. PR #16404 is a preliminary/non-English version; PR #16417 is the final submission. These are the same fix re-submitted with better language/presentation.

Comment in PR #18523 states 'Re-opened here https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw/pull/18904'. PR #18523 was reverted due to being accidental merge; the same fix (SHA-1→SHA-256 slug regression for orphaned workspace dirs) is being redone in PR #18904 as the proper venue.

CONTRIBUTOR comment in PR #14423 states: 'This change has been landed as part of the bulk Feishu integration PR: #14448'. PR #14423 (workspace protocol devDependencies fix) was merged as part of the larger bulk Feishu integration in PR #14448. These represent the same fix at different granularity levels.

All three PRs have member closures with identical truncated closing language ('If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen'). However, these are distinct technical PRs (compaction safeguard, slack threading, provider usage) with different authors and purposes. The matching closure language appears to be a standardized maintainer closure template rather than evidence of duplication. No actual duplicate functionality detected. Low confidence due to lack of substantive duplication evidence.
